'Deep in thought' might not be the best way to put it. He's holding an assault rifle, after all, and it's aimed at the observation post, jutting out of the distant trench.

The tendons of his finger are wound tight, suspended over his rifle's double-action trigger. Within a tenth of a second of receiving the order to fire, his trusty weapon will unleash the rage he's been saving up this entire time.
But yes, he's still deep in thought. The nine warriors next to him would have no idea what he was pondering in the moment.
They've all been through the same training, inherited blood and duty from their Forsaken predecessors. Like their forefathers, they are stoic, courageous instruments of death.
Bexonidas looks no different from the others if not for the insignia he wears on his shoulder, marking him as a Sergeant.
But Bexonidas has more responsibility on his shoulders than his nine brothers—he's the leader, after all.
But at this very moment, the group is in a foxhole, far away from both their base and the fight, weapons trained on their enemies at all times—yet not allowed to fire.
Their mission is simply to observe and guide the shells in.
That's why, instead of shooting, Bexonidas is simply deep in thought.
